image.altText: Jess and Jackie Morecroft stand in the driveway of their home.

items.synopsis: After a five-year court battle, the Morecrofts lost their Gold Coast family home. Now they're facing legal costs that could financially ruin them.

title.children: Couple told they never owned house they paid for 'at wits' end' over order to pay legal costs

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Warren Mundine speak at a meeting. Mr Mundine has his arm out gesturing.

items.synopsis: The two campaigns pushing for a No vote to the forthcoming Voice to Parliament referendum merge, in a move that aims to unify their message and strengthen their campaign.

title.children: Key 'No' Voice camps merge to strengthen referendum campaign

image.altText: DUPLICATE vape

items.synopsis: A Brisbane convenience store has been caught with 45,000 vapes and ordered to pay $88,000 for possessing and selling vapes containing nicotine.

title.children: Principal tips off investigators about sale of vapes to school children, resulting in conviction

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2023-24 federal budget strategy and outlook book in front of the media

items.synopsis: We now know what the government thinks it will cost to futureproof the NDIS — a whopping $74 billion in savings over the next decade. So why didn't the treasurer cite this impressive number in his budget speech, writes David Speers.

title.children: The whopping $74b budget saving that Chalmers kept quiet

image.altText: A man and woman stand in front of a tree and look sternly at the camera

items.synopsis: High valuations are great news for people wanting to sell, but those holding onto it will feel the consequences, says a peak rural lobby group after the Queensland valuer-general upped the monetary worth of some rural blocks.

title.children: Property value in this area is skyrocketing, but for some landowners, it's bad news

image.altText: A young boy in navy sitting in his wheelchair on the concrete edge of Brennan Park.

items.synopsis: One-fifth of the region is living with a disability, so why would a community park makeover leave some unable to play? This seven-year-old who uses a wheelchair is asking council to reconsider.

title.children: Zach loved playing in Brennan Park until council upgraded it, leaving him on the outer

image.altText: A man speaks in parliament wearing a suit with various politicians seated on the green benches behind him

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers used his budget speech this week to spruik the government's credentials and programs. But did he keep his facts straight?

title.children: We fact checked Jim Chalmers's budget night speech. Here's what we found

image.altText: A middle-aged woman looks at the camera, standing in front of a sandstone wall

items.synopsis: A group of people whose families profited from slavery is trying to make amends for past wrongs.

title.children: Laura Trevelyan's ancestors owned slaves, so she decided to pay reparations

image.altText: Brittany Higgins speaks at a podium.

items.synopsis: John Korn, who represented Bruce Lehrmann, recalls his "somewhat inappropriate" advice to the ACT's top prosecutor to prevent a speech at the National Press Club about sexual assault.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's lawyer demanded chief prosecutor try to stop Brittany Higgins speech

image.altText: Independent Federal MP Bob Katter looks surprised as he speaks to reporters.

items.synopsis: From running a restaurant to giving dogs a haircut, some Australians share the US president's enthusiasm for work in later life.

title.children: Like Joe Biden, Bob Katter plans to keep working past the age of 80 — and he's not alone

image.altText: Hawthorn Hawks signage at the clubs headquarters in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: The chair of the panel investigating racism allegations at Hawthorn says coaches refuse to be interviewed until they have seen documents which First Nations players say contain personal and sensitive information.

title.children: Review over racism claims at Hawthorn stalls over access to documents

image.altText: Dr Rose

items.synopsis: Rose McGready's world-renowned research could save your life if you contract malaria. But the unassuming Australian doctor now needs to raise enough money to keep her life-saving clinics afloat.

title.children: Australian doctor who's saved thousands of lives on the front line faces toughest challenge yet

image.altText: A Sydney tram with emergency workers alongside

items.synopsis: Emergency services worked to free the 16-year-old, who had critical injuries, but she died at the scene.

title.children: Teenage girl dies after becoming trapped under light rail tram in Sydney CBD

image.altText: A woman wearing blue scrubs has her arm around an older woman wearing a pink cardigan as they walk across a lush green lawn.

items.synopsis: Older Australians are increasingly opting to receive care at home, rather than in residential aged care, a shift that the federal government projects will save billions of dollars.

title.children: After 'five years of aged scare', a decline in residential aged care could deliver big budget savings

image.altText: A young blonde girl smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: Fourteen-year-old Shyanne-Lee Tatnell has not been seen or heard from since April 30. Now community members are getting involved in the search to find her.

title.children: Shyanne-Lee disappeared in Launceston 10 days ago, without a phone call or sighting since

image.altText: Man in diving gear touching the mouth of a large whale shark underwater.

items.synopsis: Making a natural history documentary is a test of patience and endurance, and Tim Winton had finally run out of both. He was trying to capture the wild beauty of his beloved Ningaloo Reef but Mother Nature wouldn't play ball.

title.children: Tim Winton picked parasites off whale shark's mouth, but that's not what 'terrified' him

image.altText: A piece of land with the Australian flag and the Chinese flag next to each other with a big crack separating the two

items.synopsis: Australia's Trade Minister Don Farrell will hold a meeting with his Chinese counterpart in Beijing this week, with hopes it could signal the trade turmoil between China and Australia will soon be over.

title.children: Trade Minister Don Farrell to visit China in push to end trade bans on barley, meat and wine

image.altText: Woman walks down cobbled street with backpack on her back.

items.synopsis: Australians are known for their passion for travel, but when a loved one goes missing overseas, it sets off an uncharted course for those back home. This is what happens next.

title.children: Where to start if a loved one goes missing overseas

image.altText: Prince Harry with a beard and furrowed brow wearing a suit and tie

items.synopsis: A British tabloid newspaper apologises to Prince Harry for unlawfully seeking information about him at the start of the royal's lawsuit against its publisher over alleged phone hacking, in which he is due to give evidence himself.

title.children: 'Blatantly unlawful': British tabloid apologises to Prince Harry

image.altText: Kaden Groves (right in blue) extends his arms after crossing the finish line on sage five of the Giro d'Italia.

items.synopsis: Australian Kaden Groves bounces back after getting caught up in a rainy stage littered with crashes, with Remco Evenepoel brought down multiple times.

title.children: Aussie Kaden Groves recovers from crash to win Giro d'Italia stage 5 as dog takes out race favourite

image.altText: Two smiling men – actors Tom Hiddleston and Chris Hemsworth – surrounded by a film crew.

items.synopsis: The federal government's plan to attract more international film and television productions to Australia is being applauded by the sector.

title.children: Film industry figures says budget boost will be a 'total game-changer'

image.altText: An image of a microscope above a petri dish with some fluid in it.

items.synopsis: Britain's fertility regulator on Wednesday confirmed the births of the UK's first babies created using an experimental technique combining DNA from three people, an effort to prevent the children from inheriting rare genetic diseases.

title.children: In UK first, babies are being born using three people's DNA in an effort to prevent rare genetic diseases

image.altText: A coal load loads coal onto a large ship

items.synopsis: Economists and energy experts say the government is short-changing Australians with planned changes to the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax that will only raise an additional $2.4 billion over five years.

title.children: 'They screwed up': Economists say the PRRT is broken and the budget doesn't really fix it

image.altText: A Ukrainian serviceman waves from a tank, as Russia's attack on Ukraine continues.

items.synopsis: A Ukrainian military unit says it has routed a Russian infantry brigade from frontline territory near Bakhmut, confirming an account by the head of Russia's Wagner Group that the Russian forces have fled.

title.children: 'Retreated': Ukraine and Wagner confirm Russian troops failing in Bakhmut

image.altText: Screenshots from the Bluesky app

items.synopsis: A new Twitter rival has emerged, backed by Twitter's co-founder and armed with an invitation-only viral marketing campaign. Will it work?

title.children: Will Bluesky replace Twitter? That may be only the start, with a plan to reshape social media

image.altText: Five images of an Indigenous artwork being painted.

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory arts minister is calling for a national investigation into allegations of interference by white assistants that are creating "reputational damage" to the Indigenous art industry.

title.children: 'Horrified' arts minister calls for national probe into 'damaging' Indigenous art claims, puts galleries on notice

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: Local shares are set to slip when the market opens, after overnight news that US inflation is cooling. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to slip after mixed day on Wall Street as inflation cools

schema.headline: Live: ASX set to slip after mixed day on Wall Street as inflation cools

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Graincorp lifts guidance, despite weaker profits
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Agribusiness company GrainCorp has posted lower half year profits but lifted its earnings guidance. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) were $383 million, down from $427 million in the previous corresponding period. Net profit after tax (NPAT) was $200 million, down from $246 million in the first half of 2022. Grancorp lifted its full year guidance: EBITDA of $500- $560 million, up from $470- $530 million. NPAT of $220- $260 million, up from $180- 220 million. GrainCorp's Managing Director and Chief Executive Robert Spurway said there was ongoing demand for Australian grain and oilseeds, supported by a bumper third crop on the east coast. "GrainCorp's export program ran at close to full capacity with 4.4mmt of grain and oilseeds exported during the half," Mr Spurway said. "Export supply chain margins remained solid, albeit not at the levels we saw last year." The company also acknowledged the death of a worker in a fatal truck accident in April at the Graincorp receival site in Moree, New South Wales.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Us inflation slows to below 5 per cent, Jim Chalmers moves to quell fears about the budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Catch up on what made financial news overnight with ABC senior business correspondent Peter Ryan:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Do the PRRT changes in the budget go far enough to fix a 'broken' Petroleum Resource Rent Tax?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The federal government will collect $2.4 billion from gas exporters through the PRRT over four years. The gas industry isn't really complaining. According to Treasury, no LNG project has ever paid the tax. Some experts say the government should've gone a lot harder.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Wall street mixed on CPI data and debt ceiling worries
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's some detail about how the US markets ended up overnight: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 30.48 points, or 0.09 per cent, to 33,531. The S & P 500 gained 18.47 points, or 0.4 per cent, at 4,137, while the Nasdaq Composite added 126.89 points, or 1 per cent, at 12,306. The Nasdaq was helped by a 4.1 per cent climb in Google's parent company Alphabet as the company rolled out more artificial intelligence for its core search product in response to competition from Microsoft Corp. Large-cap tech stocks including Apple Inc and Microsoft also gained 1.04 per cent and 1.73 per cent, respectively. The rate-sensitive S & P 500 technology sector index went up 1.2 per cent and the communication services rose 1.69 per cent. Markets reacted positively because they saw the inflation data as a small positive, with hopes rising of a rate pause. "The CPI is indicating some sort of relief in inflationary pressure. That would mean the Fed would be toward the end or already at the end of its interest rate cycle, and growth companies are most heavily affected by higher interest rates," Kevin W. Philip, a partner at investment advisor Bel Air said. Fed funds futures traders are pricing in a pause in rate increases at the central bank's June meeting, and less than a 5 per cent chance of another 25 basis point hike. However, investors also had concerns about the looming US debt ceiling. Talks on raising the US federal government's $US31.4 trillion debt ceiling entered a new phase on Wednesday as some areas of potential compromise emerged after Tuesday's White House meeting. Regional bank shares extended declines from volatile sessions last week on concerns about the sector's health. PacWest Bancorp fell 0.5 per cent, and Zions Bancorporation fell 2.7 per cent respectively. Oil and gas producer Occidental Petroleum Corp fell 3.6 per cent after its first-quarter earnings fell short of analysts' estimates. Livent Corp rose 5.2 per cent after Australian lithium miner Allkem Ltd agreed to merge with the US-based chemical manufacturing firm to create a $US10.6 billion firm. Airbnb Inc 10.9 per cent as the vacation rental booking company had fewer bookings and lower average daily rates in the second quarter. Rivian Automotive jumped 1.8 per cent after the electrical vehicle maker beat estimates for its first-quarter results and reiterated its annual production forecast. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US annual inflation slows to 4.9 per cent
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: US consumer prices slowed to below 5 per cent in April for the first time in two years, lifting hopes of an interest rate pause. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.4 per cent last month after gaining 0.1 per cent in March. The increase was in line with economists' expectations, according to Reuters. Stubbornly high rents accounted for much of the increase in inflation. However, there were pockets of relief for consumers. Food prices were unchanged for a second straight month. Grocery store prices fell 0.2 per cent after decreasing 0.3 per cent in March, posting back-to-back declines for the first time since July 2019. Fruits and vegetables, meat, fish and eggs were cheaper compared to March. Milk prices dropped 2 per cent. Natural gas prices tumbled 4.9 per cent and the cost of electricity dropped for the second straight month, blunting some of the 3 per cent jump in gasoline prices, which followed a 4.6 per cent plunge in March. The rebound came after Saudi Arabia and other OPEC+ oil producers announced further oil output cuts. Annual inflation increased 4.9 per cent, which was the smallest yearly rise since April 2021. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX SPI 200 futures: -0.2% to 7,248 points Australian dollar: -0.3% to 67.79 US cents Dow Jones: -0.09% to 33,531 points S & P 500: +0.4% to 4,137 points Nasdaq: +1% to 12,306 points FTSE: -0.3% to 7,741points EuroStoxx: -0.4% to 463 points Spot gold: -0.2% to $US2,037/ounce Brent crude: -0.8% $US76.62 /barrel Iron ore: $US103.35/tonne Bitcoin: -0.8% at $US27,453

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Good morning
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Welcome to the live markets blog. I'll be taking you through today's business, finance and economics news. Australian shares are set to follow the US and slip at the open. Inflation data in the US has cooled, but not all investors were convinced. More on that shortly.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Graincorp lifts guidance, despite weaker profits

children.content: Agribusiness company
GrainCorp
has posted lower half year profits but lifted its earnings guidance.
Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) were $383 million, down from $427 million in the previous corresponding period.
Net profit after tax (NPAT) was $200 million, down from $246 million in the first half of 2022.
Grancorp lifted its full year guidance: EBITDA of $500- $560 million, up from $470- $530 million.
NPAT of $220- $260 million, up from $180- 220 million.
GrainCorp's Managing Director and Chief Executive Robert Spurway
said there was ongoing demand for Australian grain and oilseeds, supported by a bumper third crop on the east coast.
"GrainCorp's export program ran at close to full capacity with 4.4mmt of grain and oilseeds exported during the half," Mr Spurway said.
"Export supply chain margins remained solid, albeit not at the levels we saw last year."
The company also acknowledged the death of a worker in a fatal truck accident in April at the Graincorp receival site in Moree, New South Wales.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Us inflation slows to below 5 per cent, Jim Chalmers moves to quell fears about the budget

ABC senior business correspondent Peter Ryan:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government will collect $2.4 billion from gas exporters through the PRRT over four years. The gas industry isn't really complaining. According to Treasury, no LNG project has ever paid the tax. Some experts say the government should've gone a lot harder.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Do the PRRT changes in the budget go far enough to fix a 'broken' Petroleum Resource Rent Tax?

featuredLink.title: 'They screwed up': Economists say the PRRT is broken and the budget doesn't really fix it

children.content: The federal government will collect $2.4 billion from gas exporters through the PRRT over four years.
The gas industry isn't really complaining. According to Treasury, no LNG project has ever paid the tax. Some experts say the government should've gone a lot harder.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's some detail about how the US markets ended up overnight: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 30.48 points, or 0.09 per cent, to 33,531. The S & P 500 gained 18.47 points, or 0.4 per cent, at 4,137, while the Nasdaq Composite added 126.89 points, or 1 per cent, at 12,306. The Nasdaq was helped by a 4.1 per cent climb in Google's parent company Alphabet as the company rolled out more artificial intelligence for its core search product in response to competition from Microsoft Corp. Large-cap tech stocks including Apple Inc and Microsoft also gained 1.04 per cent and 1.73 per cent, respectively. The rate-sensitive S & P 500 technology sector index went up 1.2 per cent and the communication services rose 1.69 per cent. Markets reacted positively because they saw the inflation data as a small positive, with hopes rising of a rate pause. "The CPI is indicating some sort of relief in inflationary pressure. That would mean the Fed would be toward the end or already at the end of its interest rate cycle, and growth companies are most heavily affected by higher interest rates," Kevin W. Philip, a partner at investment advisor Bel Air said. Fed funds futures traders are pricing in a pause in rate increases at the central bank's June meeting, and less than a 5 per cent chance of another 25 basis point hike. However, investors also had concerns about the looming US debt ceiling. Talks on raising the US federal government's $US31.4 trillion debt ceiling entered a new phase on Wednesday as some areas of potential compromise emerged after Tuesday's White House meeting. Regional bank shares extended declines from volatile sessions last week on concerns about the sector's health. PacWest Bancorp fell 0.5 per cent, and Zions Bancorporation fell 2.7 per cent respectively. Oil and gas producer Occidental Petroleum Corp fell 3.6 per cent after its first-quarter earnings fell short of analysts' estimates. Livent Corp rose 5.2 per cent after Australian lithium miner Allkem Ltd agreed to merge with the US-based chemical manufacturing firm to create a $US10.6 billion firm. Airbnb Inc 10.9 per cent as the vacation rental booking company had fewer bookings and lower average daily rates in the second quarter. Rivian Automotive jumped 1.8 per cent after the electrical vehicle maker beat estimates for its first-quarter results and reiterated its annual production forecast. - with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall street mixed on CPI data and debt ceiling worries

children.content: Here's some detail about how the
US markets
ended up overnight:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average
fell 30.48 points, or 0.09 per cent, to 33,531. The S
gained 18.47 points, or 0.4 per cent, at 4,137, while the Nasdaq Composite
added 126.89 points, or 1 per cent, at 12,306.
The Nasdaq was helped by a 4.1 per cent climb in Google's parent company Alphabet
as the company rolled out more artificial intelligence for its core search product in response to competition from Microsoft Corp.
Large-cap tech stocks including Apple Inc and Microsoft also gained 1.04 per cent and 1.73 per cent, respectively.
The rate-sensitive S
P 500 technology sector index
went up 1.2 per cent and the communication services rose 1.69 per cent.
Markets reacted positively because they saw the inflation data as a small positive, with hopes rising of a rate pause.

"The CPI is indicating some sort of relief in inflationary pressure. That would mean the Fed would be toward the end or already at the end of its interest rate cycle, and growth companies are most heavily affected by higher interest rates," Kevin W. Philip, a partner at investment advisor Bel Air said.
Fed funds futures traders are pricing in a pause in rate increases at the central bank's June meeting, and less than a 5 per cent chance of another 25 basis point hike.
However, investors also had concerns about the looming US debt ceiling.
Talks on raising the US federal government's $US31.4 trillion debt ceiling entered a new phase on Wednesday as some areas of potential compromise emerged after Tuesday's White House meeting.

Regional bank shares extended declines from volatile sessions last week on concerns about the sector's health. PacWest Bancorp fell 0.5 per cent, and Zions Bancorporation fell 2.7 per cent respectively.
Oil and gas producer Occidental Petroleum Corp fell 3.6 per cent after its first-quarter earnings fell short of analysts' estimates.
Livent Corp rose 5.2 per cent after Australian lithium miner Allkem Ltd agreed to merge with the US-based chemical manufacturing firm to create a $US10.6 billion firm.
Airbnb Inc 10.9 per cent as the vacation rental booking company had fewer bookings and lower average daily rates in the second quarter.
Rivian Automotive jumped 1.8 per cent after the electrical vehicle maker beat estimates for its first-quarter results and reiterated its annual production forecast.
- with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US consumer prices slowed to below 5 per cent in April for the first time in two years, lifting hopes of an interest rate pause. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.4 per cent last month after gaining 0.1 per cent in March. The increase was in line with economists' expectations, according to Reuters. Stubbornly high rents accounted for much of the increase in inflation. However, there were pockets of relief for consumers. Food prices were unchanged for a second straight month. Grocery store prices fell 0.2 per cent after decreasing 0.3 per cent in March, posting back-to-back declines for the first time since July 2019. Fruits and vegetables, meat, fish and eggs were cheaper compared to March. Milk prices dropped 2 per cent. Natural gas prices tumbled 4.9 per cent and the cost of electricity dropped for the second straight month, blunting some of the 3 per cent jump in gasoline prices, which followed a 4.6 per cent plunge in March. The rebound came after Saudi Arabia and other OPEC+ oil producers announced further oil output cuts. Annual inflation increased 4.9 per cent, which was the smallest yearly rise since April 2021. - with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US annual inflation slows to 4.9 per cent

children.content: US consumer prices slowed to below 5 per cent in April for the first time in two years, lifting hopes of an interest rate pause.
The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.4 per cent last month after gaining 0.1 per cent in March.
The increase was in line with economists' expectations, according to Reuters.
Stubbornly high rents accounted for much of the increase in inflation.
However, there were pockets of relief for consumers.
Food prices were unchanged for a second straight month.
Grocery store prices fell 0.2 per cent after decreasing 0.3 per cent in March, posting back-to-back declines for the first time since July 2019.
Fruits and vegetables, meat, fish and eggs were cheaper compared to March.
Milk prices dropped 2 per cent.
US inflation
(Reuters)

Natural gas prices tumbled 4.9 per cent and the cost of electricity dropped for the second straight month, blunting some of the 3 per cent jump in gasoline prices, which followed a 4.6 per cent plunge in March.
The rebound came after Saudi Arabia and other OPEC+ oil producers announced further oil output cuts.
Annual inflation increased 4.9 per cent, which was the smallest yearly rise since April 2021.
- with Reuters
US inflation

children.content: Agribusiness company
GrainCorp
has posted lower half year profits but lifted its earnings guidance.
Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) were $383 million, down from $427 million in the previous corresponding period.
Net profit after tax (NPAT) was $200 million, down from $246 million in the first half of 2022.
Grancorp lifted its full year guidance: EBITDA of $500- $560 million, up from $470- $530 million.
NPAT of $220- $260 million, up from $180- 220 million.
GrainCorp's Managing Director and Chief Executive Robert Spurway
said there was ongoing demand for Australian grain and oilseeds, supported by a bumper third crop on the east coast.
"GrainCorp's export program ran at close to full capacity with 4.4mmt of grain and oilseeds exported during the half," Mr Spurway said.
"Export supply chain margins remained solid, albeit not at the levels we saw last year."
The company also acknowledged the death of a worker in a fatal truck accident in April at the Graincorp receival site in Moree, New South Wales.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's some detail about how the US markets ended up overnight: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 30.48 points, or 0.09 per cent, to 33,531. The S & P 500 gained 18.47 points, or 0.4 per cent, at 4,137, while the Nasdaq Composite added 126.89 points, or 1 per cent, at 12,306. The Nasdaq was helped by a 4.1 per cent climb in Google's parent company Alphabet as the company rolled out more artificial intelligence for its core search product in response to competition from Microsoft Corp. Large-cap tech stocks including Apple Inc and Microsoft also gained 1.04 per cent and 1.73 per cent, respectively. The rate-sensitive S & P 500 technology sector index went up 1.2 per cent and the communication services rose 1.69 per cent. Markets reacted positively because they saw the inflation data as a small positive, with hopes rising of a rate pause. "The CPI is indicating some sort of relief in inflationary pressure. That would mean the Fed would be toward the end or already at the end of its interest rate cycle, and growth companies are most heavily affected by higher interest rates," Kevin W. Philip, a partner at investment advisor Bel Air said. Fed funds futures traders are pricing in a pause in rate increases at the central bank's June meeting, and less than a 5 per cent chance of another 25 basis point hike. However, investors also had concerns about the looming US debt ceiling. Talks on raising the US federal government's $US31.4 trillion debt ceiling entered a new phase on Wednesday as some areas of potential compromise emerged after Tuesday's White House meeting. Regional bank shares extended declines from volatile sessions last week on concerns about the sector's health. PacWest Bancorp fell 0.5 per cent, and Zions Bancorporation fell 2.7 per cent respectively. Oil and gas producer Occidental Petroleum Corp fell 3.6 per cent after its first-quarter earnings fell short of analysts' estimates. Livent Corp rose 5.2 per cent after Australian lithium miner Allkem Ltd agreed to merge with the US-based chemical manufacturing firm to create a $US10.6 billion firm. Airbnb Inc 10.9 per cent as the vacation rental booking company had fewer bookings and lower average daily rates in the second quarter. Rivian Automotive jumped 1.8 per cent after the electrical vehicle maker beat estimates for its first-quarter results and reiterated its annual production forecast. - with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall street mixed on CPI data and debt ceiling worries

children.content: Here's some detail about how the
US markets
ended up overnight:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average
fell 30.48 points, or 0.09 per cent, to 33,531. The S
gained 18.47 points, or 0.4 per cent, at 4,137, while the Nasdaq Composite
added 126.89 points, or 1 per cent, at 12,306.
The Nasdaq was helped by a 4.1 per cent climb in Google's parent company Alphabet
as the company rolled out more artificial intelligence for its core search product in response to competition from Microsoft Corp.
Large-cap tech stocks including Apple Inc and Microsoft also gained 1.04 per cent and 1.73 per cent, respectively.
The rate-sensitive S
P 500 technology sector index
went up 1.2 per cent and the communication services rose 1.69 per cent.
Markets reacted positively because they saw the inflation data as a small positive, with hopes rising of a rate pause.

"The CPI is indicating some sort of relief in inflationary pressure. That would mean the Fed would be toward the end or already at the end of its interest rate cycle, and growth companies are most heavily affected by higher interest rates," Kevin W. Philip, a partner at investment advisor Bel Air said.
Fed funds futures traders are pricing in a pause in rate increases at the central bank's June meeting, and less than a 5 per cent chance of another 25 basis point hike.
However, investors also had concerns about the looming US debt ceiling.
Talks on raising the US federal government's $US31.4 trillion debt ceiling entered a new phase on Wednesday as some areas of potential compromise emerged after Tuesday's White House meeting.

Regional bank shares extended declines from volatile sessions last week on concerns about the sector's health. PacWest Bancorp fell 0.5 per cent, and Zions Bancorporation fell 2.7 per cent respectively.
Oil and gas producer Occidental Petroleum Corp fell 3.6 per cent after its first-quarter earnings fell short of analysts' estimates.
Livent Corp rose 5.2 per cent after Australian lithium miner Allkem Ltd agreed to merge with the US-based chemical manufacturing firm to create a $US10.6 billion firm.
Airbnb Inc 10.9 per cent as the vacation rental booking company had fewer bookings and lower average daily rates in the second quarter.
Rivian Automotive jumped 1.8 per cent after the electrical vehicle maker beat estimates for its first-quarter results and reiterated its annual production forecast.
- with Reuters

image.altText: Two men pass that says "Lismore Courthouse". One holds a notepad over his face. The other is long-haired and bearded.

items.synopsis: The NSW Coroner's Court is told that the organiser of the Dreaming Arts Festival played guitar while Jarrad Antonovich lay dying and later described his death as a "beautiful occasion".

title.children: Man's death from kambo frog poison described as 'beautiful occasion' as his mother weeps in court

image.altText: a young man looking away from the camera. his face cannot be identified

items.synopsis: Teen brothers were found locked in their room, naked and in soiled nappies, after their father was discovered dead from a terminal illness at their home in Brisbane's northern suburbs.

title.children: Child safety officers saw teen gnawing on dog bone but failed to remove him from father's care

image.altText: Mr Santos walks as reporters hold microphones up towards him.

items.synopsis: New York republican George Santos, infamous for fabricating key parts of his life story, has been arrested on federal criminal charges.

title.children: US Republican George Santos arrested on federal criminal charges
